bioghist.p: Dr. Elston (nee Halpert) was a pediatrician born in 1895 and educated in Germany. She received her medical degree in 1920 and was married in 1922 to Friedrich (“Fritz” and “Fred”) Gustav Edelstein, an attorney. They had two sons in 1924 and 1928. She had a practice in Berlin from 1924 until 1938 when “Racial Laws” prohibited her from practicing medicine. (Dr. Elston was Jewish, though she and her husband considered themselves “racial Jews” only, as they were members of the Lutheran Church. Her son Wolfgang says she didn’t have much of a practice in those years, though as she was raising her children. She did however, do some ground-breaking work at a pediatric institute in Berlin in the early 1920s.) In 1938 she had her necessary legal documents translated into English at the American consulate. In 1939 they sent their sons (Gerhard - Gerd - and Wolfgang, or Wolf) to stay in a boarding school for refugees in England. She and Fritz immigrated to the U.S. in 1941. In 1942 she passed her NY state board exam and began work at the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. They had changed their name to Elston. Wolfgang and Gerhard came to the U.S. shortly before the end of the war. Wolfgang earned a Ph.D. at Columbia University. (He is currently Professor Emeritus at the University of New Mexico.) They lived at 242 E. 15th St. and owned two undeveloped lots in Montauk on Long Island. Fritz was teaching at Seton Hall College in New Jersey when he died in 1956. After her husband’s death, Dr. Elston moved to Gramercy Park (1962), continued to practice medicine and traveled extensively, throughout the world. (A significant portion of these materials are in German.)

scopecontent.p: Two record cartons reflecting Dr. Elston's medical career in the United States. Patient records, appointments and receipts, documents regarding her training and background in Germany, correspondence regarding her work and credentials in New York.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
